Award.AwardTitle: Building a Unified Research Agenda for K-12 Online Learning Environments to Improve STEM Outcomes for Students with Learning Disabilities and Students with Autism Spectrum Disorder

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Students with learning disabilities and those with autism spectrum disorder represent the largest and fastest growing groups of students with disabilities in U.S. public schools. These students are underperforming in STEM achievement as compared to their non-disabled peers, and these students are underprepared for college entry and success. This capacity building project will contribute to foundational knowledge about what is already known, and what needs to be studied, about K-12 online STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) education for students with learning disabilities and those with autism spectrum disorder.

Project leaders at SRI International will engage expert researchers to conduct a synthesis and gap analysis about K-12 online STEM education for students with learning disabilities and those with autism spectrum disorder. The results of the synthesis and gap analysis will be published and made available to the public. The research team will use the results from the synthesis and gap analysis to create a research agenda about K-12 online STEM education for students with learning disabilities and those with autism spectrum disorder. Expert education researchers will engage in debate about the components of the research agenda, which will also be published and made available to the public. The agenda will help education researchers identify future education research pathways and priorities focused on K-12 online STEM learning for students with and without disabilities, a rapidly growing practice in our nation's schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SRI International?s research team engaged in four primary activities designed to focus attention on an untapped resource for addressing a shortfall of workers with STEM skills and know-how. Students with learning disabilities (LD) and autism spectrum disorder (ASD) can be prepared for the growing number of jobs that require STEM knowledge and know-how by leveraging emerging technologies.

 

The culmination of the work led to preparation of a research agenda report: Emerging digital technologies in STEM learning: A research agenda for improving success of students with learning disabilities or with autism spectrum disorder. (See Attachment 1.) Below is a description of the process and key outcomes.

 

Intellectual Merit. Through the synthesis and gap analysis, the project documented the fragmentation and limits in the research knowledge base on using digital technologies to enhance academic and social outcomes of students with LD and ASD. This finding contributed to understanding the extent of the gap for framing the importance the research agenda.

 

Discussions among experts created a shared language among LD, ASD, and learning science researchers by identifying overlapping strands of research on effective instructional practices, called foundational principles for learning. The research team tailored six principles of learning, grounded in theoretical models, that represent decades of research by scholars in special education, learning sciences and developmental psychology: (1) Help students activate prior knowledge to master new concepts; (2) Use multiple means of representation to individualize learning; (3) Model the expected practice to scaffold student learning; (4) Use ongoing formative assessment with explicit feedback to bolster student outcomes; (5) Improve students? understanding of effort to increase engagement and success; and (6) Help students understand how to think to provide scaffolds for becoming independent learners. These principles of learning are building blocks of the research agenda.

 

Broader Impacts. Engaging experts through interviews and convening them to exchange ideas during a one-day summit, created a stimulating forum for a diverse group of researchers in special education, learning sciences, STEM learning, emerging technologies, and computer sciences. These exchanges opened opportunities for researchers who often work in siloed professional communities, to collaborate and frame research strategies, to build their multi-disciplinary interests and expertise, and to establish and advance a knowledge base about how atypical students learn and thrive using emerging technologies. Many of these technologies -- from augmented reality and avatars to affective computing and use of data analytics to better personalize learning ? are already available in the market place, but only now are emerging as viable supports for learning. 

Like the foundational principles of learning, the research strategies are mutually reinforcing and interlocking pieces of the agenda:

  1.  Bolstering Cross-Sector Coordination and Rapid-Paced Research
  2.  Understanding Current Use and Practice of Digital Technologies
  3.  Accelerating Research on Emerging Technologies.

The culmination of these activities resulted in publications and additional R&D. The research agenda supports NSFs vision and the nationwide goal of broader inclusion of SWD in STEM courses, careers, and opportunities while reducing the risk that digital learning will impose barriers to participation of LD and ASD students in STEM.

The agenda is published on SRI?s web site (  https://www.sri.com/work/projects/building-unified-research-agenda-k12-online-learning-environments-improve-stem-ld-asd.), and a more focused article, reaching a national policy audience, in Education Week in 2019.

The research agenda has shaped strategic opportunities for broadening improved access and learning for LD and ASD students in digital learning environments. By combining the foundational principles of learning with emerging technologies highlighted in the research agenda, new public and private funding opportunities emerged supporting opportunities to make intellectual contributions for the next 5 years and beyond:

  • The Center for Inclusive Software for Learning (CISL) is a venture style investment to create a next generation software suite that will work with Open Educational Resources (OERs) and commercial resources supporting both access and learning outcomes for students with disabilities, as well as all students.  CAST and SRI will develop a suite of OERs including a UDL player, a portable preference discovery tool, and authoring environment for K-12 content with the l principles of learning embedded in its overall framework. 
  •  SRI, CAST, and University of Kansas, developed a Google App-based curriculum and technology innovation seeking to improve higher order thinking for students with LDs, called CORGI. The technology leverages digital features that operate seamlessly with the Google Chrome and the Google classroom environment to increase the reach of specific content enhancements designed to improve outcomes. New funding supports expansion to middle schools from high schools.
  •  SAP, a software engineering company, is an industry-leader in employing people with autism. SRI is contributing to an SAP work group called, Autism at Work Initiative Research, with the goal of building a community of scholars and practitioners concerned with issues related to the preparation and employment of individuals with autism, including a research agenda and interventions needed to create an inclusive workplace.
